timeline.bodyText: It's not a huge deal, but I would prefer to keep the size and count options on separate classes since they will not be relevant to every perf test.  The root base class PerfStressOptions should only contain options which apply to every perf test.
timeline.author: mikeharder

replies.bodyText: I would also like to keep .NET and Java as consistent as possible, and these are on separate classes in .NET.
replies.author: mikeharder

replies.bodyText: I was looking to keep all the options in one class so that users can find all available options in one place. Options that don't apply to a test can have appropriate error messages or just simply not use them.
replies.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText: Also, if a test needs both size and count options, then a third class has to be created to include both options as the PerfStressTest ctor takes a single PerfTestOptions instance.
replies.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText: Discussed offline, I slightly prefer separate classes to avoid having options which don't apply to all tests, but extra options aren't a big deal.
replies.author: mikeharder

timeline.bodyText: I assume this is better for perf since we don't allocate a new array every time?
timeline.author: mikeharder

replies.bodyText: Yes, this reduces memory pressure as we don't really need to copy the data, just reading is sufficient.
replies.author: srnagar

timeline.bodyText: Should be better for perf since we don't create new flux every iteration.
timeline.author: mikeharder

replies.bodyText: Though is it safe to reuse the same flux for each iteration?  Or is the flux "used up" after the first upload so we would need to create a new one every time?
replies.author: mikeharder

replies.bodyText: Yeah, tested it by using the same flux to read multiple times. Same data was returned each time.
replies.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText: Would it also work with a static flux, if multiple instances were reading in parallel?  Or does it need to be an instance flux, so it can be reused across iterations, but each instance needs its own copy?  Shouldn't matter much for perf either way, but I like to scope variables correctly to increase understanding of the minimal test requirements.
replies.author: mikeharder

replies.bodyText: It could have been static if the since of the buffer was fixed. Since the size is determined by the options provided in the constructor, I have made this an instance flux. However, as we discussed, we could make this static and initialize in globalSetup() as the options are not going to change for a run and all instances share the same option. I didn't want to make that assumption here as it didn't matter to the performance of the test itself.
replies.author: srnagar

timeline.bodyText: Why move from static to instance?  All instances of this test should be able to upload from the same file on disk, right?
timeline.author: mikeharder

replies.bodyText: Either way would work, but my preference is to share the same file unless each test needs its own file.  It may also be slightly faster since the OS disk cache only needs to cache one file, not N files.
replies.author: mikeharder

replies.bodyText: Moving this from static to instance actually breaks the test, since the file is only created and deleted in globalSetup, not per-instance setup.
replies.author: mikeharder

replies.bodyText: Yes, I was about to update globalSetup to per instance setup but yeah, it makes sense to have a single file. I will switch this back to static.
replies.author: srnagar

timeline.bodyText: Could a single InputStream or Flux<ByteBuffer> be used for all test instances?  If so these should be static.
timeline.author: mikeharder

replies.bodyText: Just realized that to create this input stream and flux, we need PerfStressOptions which is per-instance. So, can't make this static.
replies.author: srnagar

timeline.message: Use single temp file for upload tests
